fluminibus navigarit ambros de abraham lib 4 sicut frumentú gemino molarum opere curatum nite • cir hierome 〈◊〉 prophetis euangelio non tria sed vnum tabernaculum hom 5 leuit like one cannot saile sea without feare hath first tried riuers deepe sea mystery newe lawe cannot well sounded vnlesse haue first coasted old betweene wheat betweene two milstones truth tried origen well obsetueth peter error would haue three tabernacle christ moses elia haue read saith prophet gospel three one tabernacle substance one truth prophet apostle minister house wherein diuerse mansion one shewing v onely neather roomes bring v vpper chamber christ eare passeouer disciplesmark 1415 bernard well noteth diuine scripture haue threefold gracediuinae scripturae triplicem habent gratiam deliciotae ad faporem solidae ad nutrimentú efficacesad medecinam cantic ser 67 pleasant tast solide nourishment efficacious medicine first seene specially old scripture adorned propheticall type figure meate curiously addressed tast soundnesse nourishment efficacie heale found newe thus hauing made entrance apostolicall writing haue made choice paul epistle among romanes key vnto rest augustine saith gospel iohn est contra omnes haereticos heretikes one epistle beateth downe old newe heresiesin scripturis tibi loquitur deus non minore fide quam si tibi ore ad o loqueretur de duplic martyr cyprian affirmeth scripture generall god speaketh verily spake vnto v face face diuine epistle heauenly oracle vttered deliuered god owne mouth either old hereticall position newe popish error propounded plainely may confuted epistle sayecclesiae victoria est vos aperte dicere quod sentitis c sententias vestras prodidisse superasse est hierome ad cresiphon say vtter minde plainely without equiuocating trickes sophisticated doubting hierome saith victorie church speake plainely thinke bewray opinion one conuince blesse god hath raised vp maiestie notable instrument discouering disswading popish error superstition preferring heauens saith haue beene seene yet mooue much paul preaching short time totum orbem attraxit hath drawne whole world heauens doe keepe course goe mentis paulum sublimitas omnes coelos • ce one consisteth eloquence speach curious choice word oratours among heathen excelled shall finde paul graue sober consisting rather force perswasion number word kind eloquence paul vseth martyr chrysostome saith lingua illius supra solem emicuit doctrinae que sermone supra reliquos omnes exuberavit tongue speach brighter sunne vtterance doctrine excelled rest c gaue place vnto speach vnde mercurius ab infidelibus putabatur quod sermoni praesset whereupon infidel called mercurie office speaking committed c chrysost argum epist ad roman augustine herein concurreth chrysostome although affected eloquence ea tamen sapientiam eius comitata est yet follow accompanie wisdome lib 4 de doctr christ 2 thinke otherwise paul style 1 origen saith paul hath many hyperbata auantopedota many imperfect transition clause sentence one answering breaking abruptly beza preface oleviaues commentarie maketh mention famous man nostrâ memoriâ magnus great name memorie therein concurred origen leaueth doubt whether defect style ascribed vnto paul himselfe tertius scribe 2 hierome although variable diuers matter yet thinketh paul though eloquent owne tongue yet hath pure greeke style cilicians vsed full hebraismes 3 yea paul himselfe seemeth acknowledge want eloquence 2 cor 116 though rude speaking yet knowledge 4 peter saith paul epistle many thing therein hard vnderstood thus obiected paul style contra 1 reason paul seemeth sometime breake abruptly leaue sentence imperfect sublimitie depth great mystery handleth whereby forced often breake forth admiration rom 1133 deepenes rich wisdome knowledge god vnsearchable iudgements c proceedeth also earnestnes apostle sometime seemeth extra se raptus rauished beside himselfe martyr scribe tertius thought writ otherwise paul endited therfore style manner writing imputed paul author writer beza wel inferreth nihil p • ruisse de tantis rebus non modo divinius sed ornatius aut accommodatius dici nothing could diuinely elegantly saide great matter c diuine kinde writing frequent apostle fall admiration like affectionate speaches origen well expresseth similitude fareth apostle treating diuine thing man brought prince palace lead one chamber behold glorie beautie thereof taketh diligent view astonished beginneth wonder forgetting vnde illuc venerit aut quâ egressurus sit whence came thither got againe ex praefat martyr 2 touching paul cilician speach fit conuenient seeing paul write onely learned vnlearned also attempes speach capacitie vnderstanding hebrew scripture translated greeke tongue beleeuing gentile conuersant also meete apostle frame greeke style might haue relish hebrew tongue scripture translated 3 neither doth paul acknowledge imperfection speach writing perswaded endited spirit god confesseth way concession false apostle obiected weaknes speach saith thus much effect admit num rerum scientiam etiam mihi adimetis ye also denie vnto knowledge thing 4 peter doth impute hardnes paul epistle obscuritie style rather sublimitie profunditie great mystery treateth must needes hard vnto weake vnderstanding neither epistle hard onely thing epistle vnstable vnlearned peruerred thing owne destruction 2 pet 316 gryneus notwithstanding thing obiected paul style appeareth answerable vnto matter writeth entreateth high graue diuine matter speach graue diuine peircing hierome himselfe confesseth read paul non verba sed toni • ru percipere perceiued thunder rather word origen likewise though sometime extenuateth paul style yet thus excellently writeth thereof celsus lib 3 sat scio paul ashamed gospel v 16 1 might haue beene obiected vnto paul gospel euery scorned derided among gentile euery spoken therefore apostle professeth ashamed gospel christ though seeme neuer contemptible vnto world olevian 2 ashamed preach gospel himselfe insinuateth vnto ashamed heare mart 3 chrysostome mooueth question paul saith onely ashamed reioyceth also gospel christ saith gal 614 god forbid reioyce crosse lord iesus christ thus answereth romanes lifted vp mind honour rich estimation world paul preached christ iesus crucified counted nothing world therefore first would winne ashamed gospel would come also glorie c paul effect faith much glorie gospel minus dicitur plus intelligitur lesse spoken vnderstood pareus mart faius reason following power god c sheweth euen glorie gaue vp suffered chrysostome origen oecumenius others chrysostome vseth two similitude like captaine withdraw himselfe souldiers time battell fall enemy hand captaine might said deliuer vnto enemy likewise king hath sonne giuen riot cannot reclayme leaueth himselfe experience may see owne folly theodoret also purpose vseth similitude god leaueth men themselues tanquam cymbam ab que rectore aship left without pilote theophylact likeneth god herein phisitian hauing deale vnruly patient obey precept taketh care likewise ambrose thus expoundeth tradere est permittere non incitare deliuer vp permit •• ite stirre vp damascen lib 4 de fide orthodox c 20 sheweth vse scripture call permission god action said doe onely permitteth suffereth yea pererius addeth permission god sometime nomine praecepti appellatur called name precept whereas christ saith according matthew c 198 moses suffered hardnesse heart put away wiues according marke c 103 saith moses command setus commentarie maketh two kindes permission est vna generalis one generall man suffered sinne permission called deliuering vp altera est singularis quaedam valde formidabilis singular fearefull kinde permission god punishment former sinnes suffereth one blinded hardened sinne kinde permission apostle speaketh opinion generally romanists deliuering vp vnderstood permission lyranus ordinarie gloss varablus tolet rhemists contra 1 make god onely sufferer permitter thing done doth admit double inconuenience first make god idle beholder men action like homer bringeth iuppiter feasting spotting himselfe aethiopia grecian take troy againe make god accessarie consenting vnto euill like father master house suffer seruants liue riotously giue themselues licentiousnesse though doe encourage yet hindering seemeth giue consent like inconuenience also would follow god permitter sufferer onely thing done pareus 2 obiected god suffer sinne done world could accessarie doth hinder answ god otherwise considered man suffer euill done v power hinder must guiltie lord alwaies iust euill done world stand god pleasure notwithstanding therein iust good augustine saith probando patientiam dat locum poenitentiae nolens aliquem perire c lord therein sheweth patience giuing way vnto repentance would haue perish c concludeth deus non facit voluntates malas sed vtitur ijs vt voluerit cum aliquid iniquè velle non possit iust faith shall liue place verie iustice life actiuitie soule ascribed faith doe conclude man iustified onely faith ascribed vnto faith romanists seeing place apostle pregnant iustification faith onely seeke diuerse shift obscure truth testimonie 1 costerus euchirid 170 saith word iust shall liue faith haue meaning iustum secundum fidei norman vitam dirigere iust doth direct life according rule faith contra 1 doth place word aright thus word ioyned together iust faith shall liue faith hath rather connexion first word iust last shall liue 2 apostle life vnderstandeth euerlasting saluation conuersion said v 16 gospell power god saluation euerie one beleeueth faith bringeth euerlasting saluation 2 rhemists haue shift faith together workes must vnderstood iustifie apostle saith iust shall liue faith onely purpose also bellarmine lib 1 de iustificat c 20 contra 1 whole life soule depended vpon faith partly vpon faith partly vpon workes might well said iust shall liue workes absurd speach farre blasphemie 2 apostle c 328 excludeth work concluding man iustified faith without workes lawe liue faith liue onely faith iustified onely faith without workes 3 nowe although iust iustice lyran quest 12 whether none euill done good may come thereof 1 true conclusion diuinitie euill must done sinne committed good may caused thereby contrarie apostle condemneth saith damnation theeues murtherers may matter iustice iudge worke vpon disease occasion skilfull physitian shewe skill yet therefore man choose diseased physitian may growe famous healing neither sinnes purpose ex accidente accidentally one appointed expiationem expiation poenam punishment sinne tolet annot 14 3 diuerse wayes doth written lawe whereof apostle specially speaketh reueale sinne 1 ambrose sheweth law written knowledge sinne giueth instance ioseph detested sinne adulterie mistresse enticed said quia lex ostendit peccata non impune futura lawe sheweth sinnes shall goe vnpunished also theodulus 2 written lawe peccata clarius fuerunt cognita sinnes euidently knowne knowne sinnes taken leviora qua que non cognoscebantur esse peccata smaller sinnes knowne concupiscence hierome apostle saith knowne lust vnlesse law said thou shalt lust quaedam etiam grauiora c thing lawe knowne greater gloss ordinar 3 oecumenius thus expoundeth sinne encreased knowledge lawe sinneth wittingly much grieuous offender 4 lawe written sinne knowne beeing reason law discerned beeing god nature qualitie sinne fully perfectly knowne lawe perer 5 euen knowledge sinne lawe written issue ground principle morall lawe imprinted nature minde faius 4 whereas lawe sheweth well thing honest vertuous discouereth sinne apostle onely toucheth vse lawe reueale sinne pertinent purpose shewe iustification lawe thereby haue knowledge sinne men prone vnto thing forbidden lawe duty commanded lawe doth much teach dutie god neighbour doe performe dutie beza 5 whereas apostle saith lawe commeth knowledge sinne must supply word onely lawe doth nothing else reueale sinne iudgeth condemneth sinne likewise opposition knowledge sinne remission thereof lawe onely giueth one agnition knowledge sinne remission transgression saith negatiue law transgression collection good contrarie must inferred apostle word law transgression therefore law transgression el coherence apostle word whereas added proofe former clause law causeth wrath 2 touching coherence gorrhan maketh two argument inheritance law neither remissio poenae remission punishment law causing wrath yet remissio culpae remission fault law commeth transgression gryneus maketh coherence idem est index c foreshowne transgression punishment namely law thus better doth sentence hang together apostle prooueth law causeth wrath cause thereof causeth transgression transgression set middes betweene law wrath law bringeth forth transgression transgression wrath pareus 3 seeme good argument law transgression therefore law transgression followeth answer vnto obiection pelagians concerning originall soule controv 13 pelagians papist originall sinne quite taken away baptisme 1 pelagians obiect originall sinne propagated vnto adam posteritie least remaining taken away blotted remaineth originall sinne taken away baptisme therefore extant answer must two thing considered sinne act thereof matter guilt herein great difference betweene originall actuall sinnes act transitorie remaineth guilt remitted faith christ originall sinne though guilt thereof remitted baptisme yet matter thereof corruption deprauation man nature remaineth passeth away transitorie act actuall sinnes full demonstration hereof augustine vseth two similitude like corne sowen without chaffe straw yet corne springeth seed hath circumcised beget child vncircumcised neede new circumcision father beeing regenerate new birth yet doe beget vnregenerate child sanctitie parent passeth child knowledge vertues mart 2 romanists denie remaineth corruption nature still child god baptisme say remaineth vt poena exercenda vert • ti materia fault punishment matter occasion exercising vertue lyran concluded councell trent baptisme tolli omne illud quod veram habet propriam rationem peccati taken away hath proper true nature sinne concil trident sess 5 rhemists also affirme child baptized haue neither mortall veniall sinne annot 1 ioh 1 sect 5 contra 1 confesse guilt punishment originall sinne washed away faith christ blood yet staine blot remaineth still though christ deliuered punishment due vnto sinne yet euill qualitie nature purged away namely naturall pronenes aptnes euill shall fully purged vntill resurrection shall put corruption together mortalitie purpose augustine saith well meminisse debemus omnium peccatorum plenam remissionem c must remember full remission sinnes baptisme hominis vero qualitatem non totam continuo mutari c yet qualitie condition man straite chaunged de peccator merit remissi lib 1 c 25 2 obserued chrysostome quest 21 vnder law vnder grace v 14 two thing doe encourage men fight bonitas causa facilitas victoriae goodnes cause facilitie victorie argument apostle vseth goodnesse cause continually resisteth law minde beza well noteth law member put absolutely without addition alwaies something added way explanation 2 neither doth apostle speake ceremoniall iudiciall law free first wholly obligation substance obseruing equitie lawes apostle speaketh neither morall law concupiscence flesh continually inciteth stirreth men vp 3 apostle speaketh morall law three thing considered substance obseruation thereof consequents either iustification obseruing malediction obserued question respect said free law vnder place confessed free iustification workes law question two malediction law obseruation obedience take first meant vnder law vnder grace vnder curse law haue remission sinnes christ haymo ye vnder law quae punit damnat peccatores punisheth condemneth sinner vnder grace christ remission sinnes purpose vatablus vnder grace haue conscience assured omne peccatum nobis remissum esse c sinne remitted v mercie god also calvin vnder law opera eorum non exiguntur ad severum legis examen workes exacted according seuere censure examination law thus also melancthor piscator likewise legi satisfecistis christo yea haue satisfied law christ beza refuteth interpretation vpon reason apostle speaketh remission sinnes mortification fruites righteousnesse begunne v spirit 4 doe vnderstand obseruation law respect manner substance still vnder obedience law compulsion voluntarie inclined onely vnto euill anselme calleth libertatem culpabilem culpable freedome therefore fitly distinguisheth betweene two phrase apostle saith 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 free freed iustice least sinne might imputed vnto themselues afterward v 22 saith 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 liberati freed sinne shewe freedome selues onely god concludeth haec voluntas quae libera est mali c ideo bonis libera non est quia non liberatur ab eo qui eam solus c free euill delight euill therefore free good thing freed onely make free sinne c like successe citeth thomas commentarie thus writeth semper ita que homo sive peccato fuerit sive gratia liber est à coactione non tamen semper liber est ab omni inclinatione man therefore alwaies whether sinne grace free coaction compulsion alway free inclination c affirmeth thing doe men free alwaies compulsion alwaies willeth freely without constraint willeth free time euill inclination free à necessitate necessitie inclining vnto euill owne naturall disposition controv 16 whether death wage stipend sinne v 13 stipend sinne death socinus part 3 c 8 pag 294 graunteth eternall death reward sinne necessitie mortalitie dying ••• corporall death selfe adam sinne entred created mortall state condition christ hath redeemed v sinne punishment thereof therefore corporall death punishment sinne remaineth still neither hath christ redeemed v contra 1 euident apostle speaketh death absolutely without restraint limitation meaneth death generall kind soeuer corporall death speaketh directly c 512 one man sinne entred world death sinne specially vnderstood bondage mortalitie adam transgression brought vpon posteritie 2 friuolous distinction make difference betweene death necessitie dying else mortalitie necessitie dying brought sinne death also selfe 3 adam though created possibilitie dying sinned yet possibilitie neuer haue come act actually sinned 4 christ hath indeed deliuered v punishment sinne temporall eternall hath deliuered v sinne sinnes remitted neuer laid vnto iudgement yet reliques remainder sinne vtterly extinguished lord hath effectually actually deliuered v eternall death shall neuer come neare v temporall death punishment onely hath made entrance better life hath taken away power thereof shall seaze vpon v euer shall raise v vp last day perfectly triumph ouer death euer 5 origen vnderstandeth neither eternall temporall death qua separatur anima per peccatum à deo whereby soule separated god sinne apostle made iteration thing sinne selfe spirituall death soule therefore death spoken death beside namely followeth stipend sinne euerlasting death vnto next clause opposed eternall death controv 17 distinction veniall mortall sinnes v 23 stipend wage sinne death faius place doth well confute popish distinction veniall mortall sinnes say veniall sinnes owne nature worthie death apostle noteth generall sinne whatsoeuer stipend wage thereof death sinne 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 criminall iohn speaketh c 5 sinne vnto death say thou shouldest pray c apostle speaketh sinne holy ghost shall neuer forgiuen vaine pray apostle meane criminall sinnes would follow pray conuersion taketh away difference sinnes though equall small sinnes easily pardoned great sinnes forgiuen hardly pardoned lesse punished according greatnes sinne see point synops centur 4 er 6 controv 18 euerlasting life cannot merited good workes arg 1 v 23 gift god eternall life apostle chaunging inuerting order speach whereas said stipend sinne death faith stipend righteousnes eternall life gift god c euidently sheweth euerlasting life due reward merited workes gift grace christ iesus thus chrysostome expoundeth place saith merces benefactorum vestrorum vna aeterna sed donum dei life eternall reward good workes gift god theodoret non dixit eam esse mercedem sed gratiam c saith eternall life reward grace fauour nam licet quis summam absolutam iustitiam praestiterit although one could performe perfect iustice yet temporall thing correspondent eternall theophylact non quasi retributionem laborum dat eam deus sed ex gratia per christum qui hac omnia nobis promeruerit god giueth eternal life recompence labour grace christ hath merited thing v answ aduersariesdoe concur answer euerlasting life therfore called grace quia bi meritis redditur quae gratia contulit rendred vnto workes wrought v grace pererius eternall life though due vnto good workes yet giuen freely nam merita illa principaliter à dei gratia profecta sunt merites due doe principally proceed grace god c pere quest 17 diuerse kind feare v 15 ye haue receiued spirit bondage feare 1 two kind feare seruile feare one mooued onely feare punishment kept awe obedience filialis timor filiall feare child one feareth offend god much punishment findeth lord gracious good vnto feare prophet speaketh saith feare god endureth euer iohn perfect loue excelleth feare angustine thus resembleth two kind feares seruile feare like adulterous woman afraid husband least come finde wickednesse feare seene chast wife feareth offend husband least depart 2 master sentence maketh fowre kind feare beside naturall feare death 1 mundanus timor worldly feare man forsaketh christ feare loose life good feare men altogether perniciosus pernicious dangerous 2 timor seruilis seruile feare men doe well feare punishment feare good profitable sed non sufficiens sufficient 3 feare called initialis feare beginning one feareth punishment yet mooued loue god vertue feare bonus sufficiens good feare sufficient 4 timor lumpe masse v 21 1 masse vnderstand sinne idolatrie wherewith israelite infected egypt well egyptian yet lord masse saued israelite destoyed egyptian pet martyr refuseth interpretation 1 generally deliuered apostle restraine particular kind • men 2 apostle treateth punishment inflicted god vpon rather others reason whereof euident diuersitie men workes speaketh decree purpose god beginning 2 method l de resurrect cited oecumen vnderstandeth lumpe mass • element lord shall frame body men resurrectio • rise honour dishonor great difference decree • election reprobation whereof treateth selues thing impossible must needes remaine doubt despaire obtaining heauen escaping hell declareth nature propertie iustifying faith first per 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 remoouing contrarie faith secondly per 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 declaring thereunto agreeable first whereas two speciall doubt trouble mind may obtaine heauen escape hell apostle sheweth righteousnesse faith taketh away doubt first man nowe say heart shall ascend heauen bring thither christ hath done alreadie bring christ againe thence become man v ascend againe neither man make questiō shall escape hell shall descend thither christ death hath deliuered v thence faith christ doth deliuer v doubt therefore hath faith grounded vpon passion resurrection ascention christ shall longer perplexed mind hope iustified law thus calv pulverem oris illius videre vellem per quod christus locutus est c immo non oris solum illiusin 16 c ad rom moral vlti • n sed cordis pulverem videre vellem quod si quis totius orbis cor dixerit c non peccaverit adeo enim istud cor latum fuit vt vt se susceperit integras gens videre rurfus vellem pulverem manuum quas cum tetigit vipera rogu • u decidit c vellem oculorum pulverem videre excaecatorum primò doinde ad orbis salutem respicientium vellem pedum illorum videre pulterem qui per orbem currentes non laborarunt c quid opus est singula tecensere vellem videre sepulchrum illud quo recondita sunt arma illa iustitiae armalucis isto modo aureum illud chrysostomi o divinissimi apostoli dignis ••• laudes decantat verùm licet paulus totus sit veluti sacratissimus omniū rerum pretiosarum vnum est prae caeteriscap 14 quo paulus animum verè apostolicum oftendit romanos de rebus aediaphoris altercantes summo artificio ad pacem revocare studet vos pro vestra pietate ecclesiae nostrae non dissimili dissidio laboranti succurrite veluti nutantibus suo loco motis columnis humeros supponite duo sunt que nostram ecclesiam beare possunt pax externa domestica illam nobis attulit serenissimus noster rex de quo vertu illud praedicari potest quàm quod olim de pericle suo iactabant athenienses 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 quod nemo atheniensium illius causa vestem attā vnquá induerit alteram vestra humanitas conciliabit melanthius inter athenienses dicere solebat civitatem servari oratorum dissidijs sed pastorum concordiares nostras crescere facile intelligit vestra prudentia quam vos promovere pust vp pride becommeth foolish timorous rash subiect infirmity whatsoeuer nabal proud man became foolish afterward faint hearted timorous feare died like corpus intemperatum factum quibusvis est passionibus obnoxium bodie intemperate hauing lost complexion subiect euery passion minde hauing lost humilitie prudence apt euery infirmitie like eye beeing blind maketh member blind arrogancie offered tyrant doe transgresse owne lawes doe held privatus grassator priuate assaulter otherwise lawes beare wrong rather suffer endure vse resistance band christian souldiers put sword christian haue absolute power temporall thing dispose pleasure seeth make maintenance iurisdiction vnderstand spirituall good chiefe argument vnreasonable opinion 1 pope hath sword spirituall materiall sword
